remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Hello, it's good to meet you today. I understand you have been experiencing dyspnea, especially with exertion. Can you describe when you first noticed these symptoms and if they have been getting better, worse, or staying the same?

Hello, doctor. Um, yes, I’ve been having this dyspnea for a little while now, especially when I try to do anything, like just walking to the bathroom. It’s not really getting better—I think it might even be a bit worse lately. And, well, I also have some incisional pain that’s making symptoms more uncomfortable.

Thank you for sharing that with me—it sounds very uncomfortable to experience worsening dyspnea and incisional pain during daily activities. To help guide my assessment, can you tell me if you have noticed any other symptoms such as swelling in your legs, chest discomfort, or palpitations along with your shortness of breath?

remedi_labels.value: Thank you for sharing that with me—it sounds very uncomfortable

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Well, um, I haven’t really noticed much swelling in my legs or chest discomfort. It’s mostly just the dyspnea that’s bothering me, especially when I try to move around. I just feel uncomfortable and, uh, I’d really like some relief from this.

Thank you for explaining how your symptoms are affecting your daily activities. To better understand your exertional dyspnea and poor endurance, can you tell me if you experience any shortness of breath while at rest, or is it only during physical activity?

remedi_labels.value: Thank you for explaining how your symptoms are affecting your daily activities.
shortness of breath during physical activity

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Let me think… Well, most of the time, the shortness of breath is worse when I’m doing something, like walking or even just getting up from bed—that’s when I really notice the exertional dyspnea. My endurance is pretty poor now; I get tired so easily. At rest, it’s not as bad, but sometimes I still feel a little breathless, especially if I’m lying flat. I just feel uncomfortable and, um, I’m hoping you can help me figure out what’s going on.

remedi_labels.value: hoping you can help me figure out what’s going on

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Thank you for describing your symptoms in detail. In addition to your poor endurance, you mentioned experiencing right-sided weakness—can you tell me more about when you first noticed this weakness and whether it has affected your ability to move or perform daily activities?

remedi_labels.value: when you first noticed this weakness
affected your ability to move or perform daily activities

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Oh, right, the right-sided weakness… Well, um, I think I started noticing it maybe a few days ago? It’s mostly my arm and leg on that side—they just feel kind of heavy and not as strong as usual. It’s made it harder for me to get around, and I feel more tired, kind of lethargic, even when I’m just sitting. I’m not sure if it’s related to the dyspnea or something else, but it’s definitely making symptoms more difficult. Should I be worried about this?

remedi_labels.value: heaviness and decreased strength in right arm and leg
Should I be worried about this?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried about these symptoms—right-sided weakness and poor endurance can be concerning, especially when they affect your ability to move and perform daily activities. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any changes in your speech, facial drooping, or difficulty with coordination since the weakness began?

Well, um, I haven’t really noticed any changes in my speech or any facial drooping, at least not that I’m aware of. My coordination is maybe a little off, but it’s hard to tell if that’s just from feeling so tired and weak. Actually, after I was extubated, I was quite drowsy and, uh, I think I even had trouble following commands for a bit. Also, I remember someone mentioning that my LFTs were increasing—I’m not sure if that’s important, but I thought I should mention it. I just feel so uncomfortable and, honestly, a bit worried about all these symptoms.

I can understand your anxiety—these symptoms can be unsettling, and it’s important that we address them thoroughly. Given your right-sided weakness and poor endurance, have you experienced any numbness, tingling, or loss of sensation on that side, in addition to the heaviness and weakness you described?

remedi_labels.value: I can understand your anxiety—these symptoms can be unsettling, and it’s important that we address them thoroughly.
numbness, tingling, or loss of sensation on that side

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Let me think… Actually, I don’t really have numbness or tingling, it’s more just that heaviness and weakness on my right side. I guess I haven’t lost sensation, but sometimes I do feel a little clumsy. After I was extubated, I remember being really somnolent and, um, I think there were times when I failed to follow commands. That was a bit scary for me. Is that something that happens often after surgery, or should I be more concerned? I’m just feeling so uncomfortable and would really like to know what might help with these symptoms.

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be anxious, especially with new symptoms like right-sided weakness and poor endurance after your surgery. remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Well, um, I haven’t really noticed any changes with my bladder or bowel control—those seem about the same as before. remedi_labels.value: Thank you for sharing these details—it’s understandable to feel frustrated by persistent weakness and poor endurance after surgery.

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:

My hand just doesn’t seem as steady or strong, and sometimes I feel clumsy when I try to do those symptoms. It’s frustrating because I used to be able to manage on my own, and now I need help with simple tasks.

Is this kind of weakness and poor coordination something that will get better with time, or should I be worried about something more serious? And is there anything I can do to help improve my strength and endurance? I’d really like to get back to feeling more comfortable and independent again.

Have you noticed any new difficulty with swallowing (dysphagia) or changes in your speech since these symptoms began?

Well, um, I do have a history of swallowing symptoms—I think it’s called dysphagia? I’ve had symptoms with my esophagus before, and I’ve even had botox injections for achalasia. But since these new symptoms started, I don’t think my swallowing has gotten any worse than usual. My speech seems about the same, too—no slurring or trouble getting words out that I’ve noticed.

I’m just feeling so uncomfortable with all these symptoms—especially the somnolence and right-sided weakness. Is it possible that my increased LFTs or the deconditioning could be making symptoms worse? And is there anything specific I can do to help with my recovery and get some relief? remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
I can understand why you’d be worried about these ongoing symptoms, especially after a major surgery and with your medical history of interstitial lung disease and pulmonary hypertension. Based on your description—persistent right-sided weakness, somnolence, exertional dyspnea, and poor endurance—these symptoms could be related to a combination of deconditioning, possible neurological changes, and your underlying cardiopulmonary conditions. I recommend a comprehensive neurological examination and brain imaging to assess for any acute neurological causes, as well as continued monitoring of your liver function diagnostic evaluations and hemoglobin levels.

In addition to these assessments, starting a structured physical therapy program can help address your deconditioning and gradually improve your strength and endurance. It’s also important to closely monitor for any new symptoms such as fever, jaundice, or worsening shortness of breath.

To guide further management, have you recently had a formal cardiac assessment, such as an echocardiogram, since your surgery to evaluate your heart function in relation to your current symptoms?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Thank you for sharing your concerns and for being so attentive to your symptoms—your careful monitoring is very important, especially given your medical history and current anticoagulation therapy. Based on your persistent right-sided weakness, exertional dyspnea, somnolence, and increased bruising while on warfarin, my clinical assessment is that you may be experiencing a combination of deconditioning, possible neurological changes, and effects related to your cardiac and hepatic function; your mild anemia may also be contributing to your poor endurance.

I recommend proceeding with a neurological examination and brain imaging, as well as a formal cardiac assessment (such as an echocardiogram) to further evaluate your symptoms. Physical therapy will be essential for rehabilitation and regaining strength. Please continue to monitor for any signs of active bleeding (such as nosebleeds, blood in urine or stool, or significant bruising), and if these occur or if your neurological symptoms worsen suddenly, assessk immediate medical attention.

While recovery can take time after major surgery, especially with your medical history, many patients do improve with targeted rehabilitation and close monitoring. Have you had your most recent INR (international normalized ratio) examineed to ensure your warfarin therapy is within the therapeutic range?
